								As a person who did boxing as a hobby in college, I am very happy with this game and defintiely recommend it (especially because it is not a wave shooter like the rest of the VR games out there). I play on oculus, and I only have 180 sensors, so I have to be facing front in order for it to read my glove placement. It works on the startup when I step on the scale...it works when I spawn at the fight board... and then in the match, it spawns the fighter on my right, instead of right in front of me. so, I have to turn to my right to fight, but now my right sensor is blocked by my body. This causes my right hand to either not respond, or to just fly off into space at random periods. Crowding: If you watch actual boxers, they move in to attack, throw a few punches, and back out so they don't get hit. Old blue, and a few of the other guys move in, but they never move out. they just stay in the pocket, and either hit, or be hit. The problem is, I don't want to stay in there with them. I move back, and they follow. eventually I hit the wall, in reality. I have no way to circle around them to escape, so I'm just stuck there getting pounded on.

								Tried out the Beta and still enjoyed the game. The added arms gives you advantage to block attacks, I like the new damage system being reduced when you partially block an attack, even using your arms. I was amazed how close to accurate your arms are at, though it needs some work according to the developer but I trust him based from my experience, it looks like it is heading to the right direction. Always remember to let the game calibrate your body to get proper proportions, also calibrate each time you switch the vive to another friend. Heavy punching opponents (There is a new guy who is like a heavy weight with heavy punches) are tougher to block, sometimes it requires 2 hands to block heavy shots and blocking using 1 arm/glove sometimes is not enough. Your arms and the opponents arms react like that of the game Fight Night series where it can tangle at some point but not to an extent and sill feels like arcade. The damage you can give now is based off the speed of your punch, it gets challenging and pushes your strength specially when you are already tired at some point. Early releases feels more arcade, this one still is but with a bit of realism, punches do not fully go through their heads depending on the strength of punch, it can still go through their bodies but sometimes it stops at some point, your arms/gloves might not be where they are but they are just only inches off and I like the feel and most of the time it is on point. Some might not like it, but I guess because it feels different, for those who haven't tried the game yet and go straight to beta, you will still enjoy even with the new changes, they have their equal ups and downs, it is still the same game, you will sweat a lot and have lots of fun doing exercise, this is the best exercise you can get whether you have boxing skills or not. I have some boxing skills taught from my grandpa and if you have, you will enjoy this game more because there are many areas in this game that applies to the boxing discipline, this is the best VR boxing you get, of course you can always exploit the game and beat the guys easy, as they have their technical limitations, part of the fun in the game is somewhat up to you, how you react and move yourself in the playing field, boxers will try this game and apply like they shadow box on real opponent, casual players will just barage the opponent as many hits as they can, if you are a fan of Fight Night series then this game is the closes VR game to that and of real life boxing.Recommendations- Option to adjust the starting point of your arms (shoulder) It looks closer to my head. Or overall manual calibration.- Improve opponents reaction when doing sidestep, they look dumb when I keep on circling them.- Apply illegal blow warnings (referee warning, kinda) when hitting at the back of the multiple times when playes go behind them.- I don't think the body works well unless we have sensors to detect, leaning forward does not work in this game as your body just moves forward like a hanging slab attached to your neck.- Maybe tweak the damage system to add more damage when countering their punches and less when opponents expect to be attacked or when they are in defensive mode. In real boxing you tend to get hurt more on punches you don't expect.- Maybe try to play with special punches, a charge punch by holding a button to charge it.- Add movement to characters to dodge your attacks, duck, lean way and moving back to lure you to an attack or sidestep and move away when hurt.- Add player knocked down on floor, not following the downed players body because this can cause nausea, maybe just put a downed players body on the floor and add Taunt animation on the characters taunting the downed players body, this will be more challenging and will provoke the players. It would be funny to have the player (John Doe) wearing a VR headset and holding the vive controllers with gloves getting knocked down on the floor.

								The Thrill of the Fight! Is a breakthrough game for VR. Looking at the video and screenshots alone makes you wonder, will this be any good? Well, the answer is YES! This game is phenomenal, and I do not just say it to make it sound good.As soon as you are thrown into it, you get the feel that you are actually there in the training gym. The scale of the players is immensely accurate. Graphics:Graphics are one thing while gameplay is a whole different thing. ToTF has managed to settle truly in between these two things as the visuals are fine the way they are. The players have great details as well as the boxing ring. The only downside I would name is, the background or “Crows” if you can call it, that is a bit lacking at the current release, but hey, that’s not the main focus of the developer at this time.Gameplay:This is where this game truly shines, you are put into a ring to go through 5 opponents (At the time of writing this review) which all vary in personality/skills and size. You immediately raise your guard as you know this will be a fight! This game allows you to do different types of punches such as Jabs, Deflections, Uppercuts and throw straight punches/lunges as well as a sophisticated dodge system which you can combine with Ducking, strafing around your opponent, raising your gloves to guard, but be careful, the side of your head can be open for the opponent to strike, so you really have to managed your blocking, which is great!The enemy AI is a work in progress, but at its current state it is polished enough to be called, more than acceptable! They block, move slightly around the ring and adjust to your play space accordingly. Based on the fighter you face, they might have different abilities. Without spoiling the fights to anyone, think about agility, size, force and weight. Overall, this is a must buy game for anyone, whether they have played boxing before or not. This game will have you sweating after fighting with all the opponents. This promotes an active game style for sure.  The developer is constantly updating the game, on a weekly basis and is delivering new opponents, promised game modes and tweaks to the fighting system. Do yourself a favor and buy this game, you will not regret it as it is pure fun to jab someone in the face, the only thing missing is the feedback of doing so in real life!

								Really enjoying this! Mechanics are getting better and better with each update and the feel of boxing is pretty realistic. 								Boxing capitalizes on the strengths of the Vive while minimizing its weaknesses.  In its 7th update, TotF has progressed from its humble origins into a legitimate game, rather than a promising tech demo.  There is a solid core experience with different enemy styles. For those with boxing experience, you can do all the stuff you should be doing, and it's effective.  If you have a large enough VR space, you can use footwork effectively.TotF is one of the best-designed games available for the Vive currently.  The concept works with the hardware, and the execution is good.  No teleportation or button presses to take you out of the experience; you're just punching and trying not to get punched.  It makes sense to the novice, but also allows the use of skill.  There's a lot more that can be done with VR fisticuffs, but for now this is as good as it gets.

								Boxing capitalizes on the strengths of the Vive while minimizing its weaknesses.  In its 7th update, TotF has progressed from its humble origins into a legitimate game, rather than a promising tech demo.  There is a solid core experience with different enemy styles. For those with boxing experience, you can do all the stuff you should be doing, and it's effective.  If you have a large enough VR space, you can use footwork effectively.TotF is one of the best-designed games available for the Vive currently.  The concept works with the hardware, and the execution is good.  No teleportation or button presses to take you out of the experience; you're just punching and trying not to get punched. 								Review as of Update 2 (Lightning Luis just added):Ok so this is obviously an early access game, so there isn't that much content. With that said, what there is seems to be pretty good. Full disclosure: I used to do full contact fighting, sorta like MMA but before that became a specific thing, and used at different times boxing gloves and juijitsu gloves. Overall things feel pretty good. You hold the controllers in a way that makes sense for this context. The opponents are really easy, but it gives you a little workout since they block just about everything unless they're hitting or about to hit. There isn't that much of a sense of actually making contact though, outside the sound. I dunno if it's the shading/lighting or what but it's hard to tell if I landed something (the lack of animation on impact has this effect as well). Body shots don't get any response unless they KO the guy, but the guys KO with the same animation as if you clocked him on the jaw. The characters aren't the most realistic looking, their physiques are kinda weirdly shapes, but it's good enough. I think the dev should look into the NVidia funhouse demo where you punch the little wackamole kind of things. They felt much more real to hit due to their physics and reactions. I would like to see things like hit counts, %'s, some kind of indication of whether I'm hitting hard or soft (just base this off velocity I guess?), and better detection of whether the guy is actually blocking my strikes. Basically I'd like that as the player becomes a better boxer all around he's rewarded. If I can throw 200+ fast jabs/round, and target them through his guard, that'd be nice to get rewarded for. The motivation would be there to become genuinely stronger/faster, so you can overcome the tougher opponents. That'd be truly unique.

Just a couple of things to be aware of:* You'll want a pretty large play area. The game is fairly dependant on mobility (steping, ducking, weaving). When you are backing onto the edge of your playspace, there is no warning system other than the VIVE chaperone.* Use the straps on your tracked controllers and tighten your headstrap. It is really easy to get immersed in the game and forget you're wearing $1400 (AUD) worth of headgear. More than a few times, a swift duck nearly caused the thing to fly right off my head.Despite that, I highly recommend this game.
